dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Ben Bernanke and the Fed just announced their third interest rate cut this year, you know, in response to the weakening economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ben Bernanke and the Fed just announced their third interest rate cut this year, you know, in response to the weakening economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. The Federal Reserve has raised a key interest rate for the third time this year in response to a strong U.S. economy and signaled that it expects to maintain a pace of gradual rate hikes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they uh, signaled more gradual cuts ahead, which is interesting because they also added that line about monetary policy remaining accommodative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they uh, signaled more gradual cuts ahead, which is interesting because they also added that line about monetary policy remaining accommodative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserve has raised a key interest rate for the third time this year in response to a strong U.S. economy and signaled that it expects to maintain a pace of gradual rate hikes. The FOMC also removed a sentence from its statement that had said monetary policy remains accommodative, although Chairman Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting press conference that this does not mean that the Fed will not respond to negative economic developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but Bernanke was quick to clarify that doesn't mean they'll automatically respond to positive news, which is a bit of a mixed signal, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but Bernanke was quick to clarify that doesn't mean they'll automatically respond to positive news, which is a bit of a mixed signal, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The FOMC also removed a sentence from its statement that had said monetary policy remains accommodative, although Chairman Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting press conference that this does not mean that the Fed will not respond to negative economic developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the whole yield curve situation—short-term rates rose, longer-term moved similarly, so it flattened out. But an inverted curve is what really spooks people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the whole yield curve situation-short-term rates rose, longer-term moved similarly, so it flattened out. But an inverted curve is what really spooks people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the immediate aftermath of the Feds move, the yield curve grew flatter as short-term rates rose while longer-term rates did not move or fell slightly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Historically that inversion has been a huge recession predictor, but Jamie Dimon says it's not that big a problem. I'm not sure I buy that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Historically that inversion has been a huge recession predictor, but Jamie Dimon says it's not that big a problem. I'm not sure I buy that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The inverted yield curve is not that big a problem, says Rafael Bostic, CEO...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Me neither, especially with unemployment at 3.9%, which is basically full employment by past standards, but now we're seeing deflationary pressure instead of inflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me neither, especially with unemployment at three point nine percent, which is basically full employment by past standards, but now we're seeing deflationary pressure instead of inflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At 3.9%, unemployment is arguably at a rate that in the past has marked full employment, and prices of goods, labor, and assets are rising across the board. Over the past decade, the Fed has fought to keep prices from deflating, but now Powell is presiding over a central bank that is keeping an eye out for signs that inflation is running too hot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—Bernanke's Fed is watching for deflation running too hot, which is a total shift from the last decade's fight against inflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-Bernanke's Fed is watching for deflation running too hot, which is a total shift from the last decade's fight against inflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the past decade, the Fed has fought to keep prices from deflating, but now Powell is presiding over a central bank that is keeping an eye out for signs that inflation is running too hot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the pricing data from Goldman Sachs—S&P 500 companies saw 3.3% price growth year over year, but wage growth is only at 1.4%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the pricing data from Goldman Sachs-S&P five hundred companies saw three point three percent price growth year over year, but wage growth is only at one point four percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A research note this week from UBS shows that pricing over the last three months for companies in the S&P 500 grew 3.3% from one year ago, 2.3% excluding the energy sector. Wage growth for the S&P 500, excluding energy, is running at 2.4% a year, but down from highs earlier this year above 3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is way below that 5% threshold Goldman mentions for profit cycles to turn higher. So corporate margins could be under pressure if costs outpace what they can charge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is way below that five percent threshold Goldman mentions for profit cycles to turn higher. So corporate margins could be under pressure if costs outpace what they can charge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UBS says that corporate profit cycles have historically turned lower once annual wage growth tops 4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they highlighted specific sectors—energy, utilities, materials have weaker headwinds thanks to decent pricing growth, but transportation wages slowed a full percentage point last quarter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they highlighted specific sectors-energy, utilities, materials have weaker headwinds thanks to decent pricing growth, but transportation wages slowed a full percentage point last quarter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Transportation stocks saw wage growth slow by two percentage point in the most recent quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So if deflation keeps up, we gotta watch those metrics closely. And then there's the stocks with weak pricing power—Goldman's sell list includes big names like Bank of America and Microsoft.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if deflation keeps up, we gotta watch those metrics closely. And then there's the stocks with weak pricing power-Goldman's sell list includes big names like Bank of America and Microsoft.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To find companies with strong pricing that could outperform the market, UBS searched the S&P 500 for stocks that rank in the top third for price growth and those in the top third ranked by three-month change in price growth, and then selected only those stocks on which the firm has a buy rating. Among those that make the cut are big banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), as well as retail juggernaut Amazon (AMZN) and entertainment giant Walt Disney (DIS).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and dividend decreases matter too—shareholders can't ignore 3% inflation eating into returns anymore. It's a whole different ball game now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and dividend decreases matter too-shareholders can't ignore three percent inflation eating into returns anymore. It's a whole different ball game now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That wasnt much of a hurdle in the past decade when inflation was at negligible rates, but now running at 3% per year, inflation should be a on your radar when you decide what to do with your money.

artist_script:
Ben Bernanke and the Fed just announced their third interest rate cut this year, you know, in response to the weakening economy.
HostB: Yeah, and they uh, signaled more gradual cuts ahead, which is interesting because they also added that line about monetary policy remaining accommodative.
HostA: Right, but Bernanke was quick to clarify that doesn’t mean they’ll automatically respond to positive news, which is a bit of a mixed signal, honestly.
HostB: And then there’s the whole yield curve situation—short-term rates rose, longer-term moved similarly, so it flattened out. But an inverted curve is what really spooks people.
HostA: Historically that inversion has been a huge recession predictor, but Jamie Dimon says it’s not that big a problem. I’m not sure I buy that.
HostB: Me neither, especially with unemployment at 3.9%, which is basically full employment by past standards, but now we’re seeing deflationary pressure instead of inflation.
HostA: Exactly—Bernanke’s Fed is watching for deflation running too hot, which is a total shift from the last decade’s fight against inflation.
HostB: And then there’s the pricing data from Goldman Sachs—S&P 500 companies saw 3.3% price growth year over year, but wage growth is only at 1.4%.
HostA: Which is way below that 5% threshold Goldman mentions for profit cycles to turn higher. So corporate margins could be under pressure if costs outpace what they can charge.
HostB: And they highlighted specific sectors—energy, utilities, materials have weaker headwinds thanks to decent pricing growth, but transportation wages slowed a full percentage point last quarter.
HostA: So if deflation keeps up, we gotta watch those metrics closely. And then there’s the stocks with weak pricing power—Goldman’s sell list includes big names like Bank of America and Microsoft.
HostB: Yeah, and dividend decreases matter too—shareholders can’t ignore 3% inflation eating into returns anymore. It’s a whole different ball game now.
